metadata.title: China reports more than 200 infections with new coronavirus from Wuhan
affiliations: University of Sydney. As more people learn about the disease, more will go to doctors, Kamradt-Scott says, even with mild symptoms, whereas previously they might have just stayed home. And doctors are now on the lookout for the new disease. “The result is that you see a sudden surge in cases,” he says. But, “If we continue to see this trend continue over the next week where there are 50 to 100 new cases every day, then that would be cause for further concern.”
metadata.abstract: Meanwhile, the pattern of spread makes it increasingly likely that the virus can transmit between people, some experts say. “Uncertainty and gaps remain, but it’s clear that there is some level of person-to-person transmission,” Jeremy Farrar, head of the Wellcome Trust, said in a statement today.
metadata.author: Dennis Normile

introduction: The outbreak of a new virus that began in the Chinese city of Wuhan last month appears to be far from over. Today, Chinese health authorities reported that more than 130 new pneumonia cases caused by the virus were identified over the weekend, bringing the total in China alone to 201, including three outside of Wuhan. There has also been a third death from the infection, and South Korea has now reported a case as well—the third country outside China to do so.

Meanwhile, the pattern of spread makes it increasingly likely that the virus can transmit between people, some experts say. “Uncertainty and gaps remain, but it’s clear that there is some level of person-to-person transmission,” Jeremy Farrar, head of the Wellcome Trust, said in a statement today.

participants.context: The outbreak of a new virus that began in the Chinese city of Wuhan last month appears to be far from over. <mark class="stats">Today, Chinese health authorities reported that more than 130 new pneumonia cases caused by the virus were identified over the weekend, bringing the total in China alone to 201, including three outside of Wuhan</mark>. There has also been a third death from the infection, and South Korea has now reported a case as well—the third country outside China to do so

And doctors are now on the lookout for the new disease. “The result is that you see a sudden surge in cases,” he says. <mark class="stats">But, “If we continue to see this trend continue over the next week where there are 50 to 100 new cases every day, then that would be cause for further concern.”</mark>. The outbreak began in mid-December 2019 in Wuhan, a major city and travel hub in central China

One week ago, new cases seemed to be tapering off—but then more patients started to appear. <mark class="stats">Early on Monday local time, the Wuhan Municipal Health Commission reported identifying 59 new cases on 18 January and an additional 77 on 19 January</mark>. One patient died on Saturday, bringing the number of deaths to three

Nine remain critically ill. <mark class="stats">Authorities separately confirmed that two patients had been identified in Beijing and one in Shenzhen, a major city bordering Hong Kong</mark>. Before the new case in South Korea, two travelers from Wuhan were found to be infected in Thailand and one in Japan

Authorities separately confirmed that two patients had been identified in Beijing and one in Shenzhen, a major city bordering Hong Kong. <mark class="stats">Before the new case in South Korea, two travelers from Wuhan were found to be infected in Thailand and one in Japan</mark>. Health authorities worry about further spread of the virus as several hundred million Chinese are expected to travel domestically to visit relatives during the weeklong Lunar New Year festivities, which start on 25 January

But Wuhan health authorities have said they have found no evidence of it so far. <mark class="stats">They have tracked 817 close contacts of patients, of whom 727 were cleared of illness; the remaining 90 are still under observation</mark>. Wuhan authorities have also reported that no health care workers tending to coronavirus patients have become ill, a common occurrence when a new virus with the ability to spread between people emerges. (It is not clear whether authorities have tested patient contacts for antibodies to the virus, which would be a sign that they were infected at some point but recovered.)

summary: The outbreak of a new virus that began in the Chinese city of Wuhan last month appears to be far from over.
China reports more than 200 infections with new coronavirus from Wuhan

Chinese health authorities reported that more than 130 new pneumonia cases caused by the virus were identified over the weekend, bringing the total in China alone to 201, including three outside of Wuhan.
There has been a third death from the infection, and South Korea has reported a case as well—the third country outside China to do so.
“The sudden spike in cases is disconcerting, but not entirely unexpected,” says Adam Kamradt-Scott, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Sydney.
As more people learn about the disease, more will go to doctors, Kamradt-Scott says, even with mild symptoms, whereas previously they might have just stayed home.
The outbreak began in mid-December 2019 in Wuhan, a major city and travel hub in central China.
By 8 January, Chinese scientists had identified a new member of the coronavirus family as the likely culprit.
New cases seemed to be tapering off—but more patients started to appear.
On Monday local time, the Wuhan Municipal Health Commission reported identifying 59 new cases on 18 January and an additional 77 on 19 January.
Before the new case in South Korea, two travelers from Wuhan were found to be infected in Thailand and one in Japan.

Health authorities worry about further spread of the virus as several hundred million Chinese are expected to travel domestically to visit relatives during the weeklong Lunar New Year festivities, which start on 25 January.
The patient that turned up in Japan after traveling to Wuhan reportedly said he had never been to the Huanan market.
Wuhan authorities have reported that no health care workers tending to coronavirus patients have become ill, a common occurrence when a new virus with the ability to spread between people emerges.
(It is not clear whether authorities have tested patient contacts for antibodies to the virus, which would be a sign that they were infected at some point but recovered.)
The virus does not currently appear to be especially virulent and in the majority of cases has caused mild illness.

Introduction: The outbreak of a new virus that began in the Chinese city of Wuhan last month appears to be far from over.
China reports more than 200 infections with new coronavirus from Wuhan

Chinese health authorities reported that more than 130 new pneumonia cases caused by the virus were identified over the weekend, bringing the total in China alone to 201, including three outside of Wuhan.
Results: There has been a third death from the infection, and South Korea has reported a case as well—the third country outside China to do so.
“The sudden spike in cases is disconcerting, but not entirely unexpected,” says Adam Kamradt-Scott, an infectious diseases specialist at the University of Sydney.
As more people learn about the disease, more will go to doctors, Kamradt-Scott says, even with mild symptoms, whereas previously they might have just stayed home.
The outbreak began in mid-December 2019 in Wuhan, a major city and travel hub in central China.
By 8 January, Chinese scientists had identified a new member of the coronavirus family as the likely culprit.
New cases seemed to be tapering off—but more patients started to appear.
On Monday local time, the Wuhan Municipal Health Commission reported identifying 59 new cases on 18 January and an additional 77 on 19 January.
Before the new case in South Korea, two travelers from Wuhan were found to be infected in Thailand and one in Japan.

Health authorities worry about further spread of the virus as several hundred million Chinese are expected to travel domestically to visit relatives during the weeklong Lunar New Year festivities, which start on 25 January.
The patient that turned up in Japan after traveling to Wuhan reportedly said he had never been to the Huanan market.
Conclusion: Wuhan authorities have reported that no health care workers tending to coronavirus patients have become ill, a common occurrence when a new virus with the ability to spread between people emerges.
(It is not clear whether authorities have tested patient contacts for antibodies to the virus, which would be a sign that they were infected at some point but recovered.)
The virus does not currently appear to be especially virulent and in the majority of cases has caused mild illness.
